====June - complimentary harvest paintings==== ''Harvest,'' named by Van Gogh himself, or ''Harvest at La Crau, with [[Montmajour Abbey|Montmajour]] in the Background'' is made in horizontal planes. The harvested wheat lies in the foreground. In the center the activities for harvest are represented by the haystack, ladders, carts and a man with a pitchfork. The background is purple-blue mountains against a turquoise sky. He was interested in depicting "the essence of country life."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghmuseum.nl/vgm/index.jsp?page=2607&lang=en#moretotell |title=The Harvest, 1888 |year= |work=Collection |publisher=Van Gogh Museum |accessdate=April 2, 2011}}</ref> In June Van Gogh wrote of the landscape at [[La Crau]] that it was "beautiful and endless as the sea." One of his most important works, the landscape reminded him of paintings by 17th century [[Dutch Golden Age painting|Dutch masters]], [[Jacob Isaakszoon van Ruisdael|Ruysdael]] and [[Philip de Koninck|Philips Koninck]].<ref name="Leeuw">{{cite book | title=The Letters of Vincent van Gogh |author1=Van Gogh, V |author2=Leeuw, R |lastauthoramp=yes | editor=van Crimpen, H |editor2=Berends-Albert, M. | publisher=Penguin Books | location=London and other locations | year=1997 | origyear=1996 | page=F497 | isbn= | url= }}</ref> He also compared this work favorably with his painting ''The White Orchard.''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.webexhibits.org/vangogh/letter/18/497.htm |title=Letter from Vincent van Gogh to Theo van Gogh Arles, 12 or 13 June 1888 |editor=Harrison, R |year=2011 |work= |publisher=Webexhibits |accessdate=April 6, 2011}}</ref>
''Wheat Stacks in Provence,'' made about the 12th or 13 June,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kmm.nl/object/KM%20108.785/Wheat-stacks-in-Provence |title=Wheat Stacks in Provence | year= | work=Collection |publisher=Kröller-Müller Museum |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref> was intended by Van Gogh to be a complimentary work to the ''Harvest'' painting.<ref>{{cite book | title=Van Gogh and Gauguin: The Search for Sacred Art | author=Silverman, D | publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux | location=New York | year=2000 | page=444 | isbn= | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8c9jt9AToD0C&pg=PA444# }}</ref> Ladders appear in both paintings which help to create a [[pastoral]] feeling.<ref>{{cite book | title=Van Gogh's Gardens | author=Fell, D | publisher=Simon & Schuster | location=United Kingdom | year=2001 | page=96 | isbn=0-7432-0233-3 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QssD77mFRkkC&pg=PA96 }}</ref>

===Saint-Rémy=== In May 1889, Van Gogh voluntarily entered the asylum<ref name="Met Article">{{cite web |url=http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/gogh/hd_gogh.htm |title=Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History | date=2000–2011 | work=Thematic Essay, Vincent van Gogh | publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art | accessdate=March 25, 2011}}</ref> of St. Paul<ref name="Minn Art">{{cite web |url=http://minneapolis.institute.art.museum/viewer/detail.php?v=12&id=1218 |title=Olive Trees, 1889, van Gogh | date= | work=Collection | publisher=Minneapolis Institute of Arts | accessdate=March 25, 2011}}</ref> near [[Saint-Rémy-de-Provence|Saint-Rémy]] in Provence.<ref name="Met Olive Trees">{{cite web |url=http://www.metmuseum.org |title=Olive Trees, 1889, Van Gogh | date=2000–2011 | work=Collection | publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art | accessdate=March 25, 2011}}</ref> There Van Gogh had access to an adjacent cell he used as his studio. He was initially confined to the immediate asylum grounds and painted (without the bars) the world he saw from his room, such as ivy covered trees, lilacs, and irises of the garden.<ref name="Met Article"/><ref name="VGM">{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghmuseum.nl/vgm/index.jsp?page=12267&lang=en |title=The Therapy of Painting | date= | work= | publisher=Van Gogh Museum |accessdate=March 25, 2011}}</ref> Through the open bars Van Gogh could also see an enclosed wheat field, subject of many paintings at Saint-Rémy.<ref name="Leeuw 604">{{cite book | title=The Letters of Vincent van Gogh |author1=Van Gogh, V |author2=Leeuw, R |lastauthoramp=yes | editor=van Crimpen, H |editor2=Berends-Albert, M. | publisher=Penguin Books | location=London and other locations | year=1997 | origyear=1996 | page=F604 | isbn= | url= }}</ref> As he ventured outside of the asylum walls, he painted the wheat fields, olive groves, and cypress trees of the surrounding countryside,<ref name="VGM"/> which he saw as "characteristic of Provence." Over the course of the year, he painted about 150 canvases.<ref name="Met Article"/>
====The Wheat Field==== {{main|The Wheat Field}} Van Gogh worked on a group of paintings of [[The Wheat Field|group of paintings of the wheat field]] that he could see from his cell at Saint-Paul Hospital. From the studio room he could see a field of wheat, enclosed by a wall. Beyond that were the mountains from Arles. During his stay at the asylum he made about twelve paintings of the view of the enclosed wheat field and distant mountains.<ref name="PMA">{{cite web |url=http://www.philamuseum.org/collections/permanent/82820.html?mulR=32251%7c1 |title=Rain |year=2011 |work=Collections |publisher=Philadelphia Museum of Art |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref> In May Van Gogh wrote to Theo, "Through the iron-barred window I see a square field of wheat in an enclosure, a perspective like Van Goyen, above which I see the morning sun rising in all its glory."<ref>{{cite book | title=Van Gogh and God: A Creative Spiritual Quest | author=Edwards, C | publisher=Loyola Press | location=Chicago | year=1989 | page=104 | isbn=0-8294-0621-2 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fYA9QzwvsekC&pg=PA104 }}</ref> The stone wall, like a picture frame, helped to display the changing colors of the wheat field.<ref name="Fell40"/>

====Wheat field with cypresses==== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | header = | header_align = center | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = right | footer_background = | width = | image1 = Vincent van Gogh - Wheat Field with Cypresses - Google Art Project.jpg | width1 = 160 | caption1 = ''[[Wheat Field with Cypresses]]'', June–July 1889, Oil on canvas, 73 x 93.4 cm, [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], New York (F717) | image2 = Vincent Van Gogh 0020.jpg | width2 = 160 | caption2 = ''A Wheat Field, with Cypresses,'' September 1889, [[National Gallery]], [[London]] (F615) }}The wheat field with cypresses paintings were made when van Gogh was able to leave the asylum. Van Gogh had a fondness for cypresses and wheat fields of which he wrote: "Only I have no news to tell you, for the days are all the same, I have no ideas, except to think that a field of wheat or a cypress well worth the trouble of looking at closeup."<ref name="Edwards102" />
In early July, Van Gogh wrote to his brother Theo of a work he began in June, ''[[Wheat Field with Cypresses]]'': "I have a canvas of cypresses with some ears of wheat, some poppies, a blue sky like a piece of [[Scotch plaid]]; the former painted with a thick impasto . . . and the wheat field in the sun, which represents the extreme heat, very thick too." Van Gogh who regarded this landscape as one of his "best" summer paintings made two additional oil paintings very similar in composition that fall. One of the two is in a private collection.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metmuseum.org/works_of_art/collection_database/european_paintings/wheat_field_with_cypresses_vincent_van_gogh/objectview.aspx?collID=11&OID=110000977 |title=Wheat Field with Cypresses |year=2000–2011 |work= |publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref>
London's [[National Gallery]] ''A Wheat Field, with Cypresses'' painting was made in September<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/paintings/vincent-van-gogh-a-wheatfield-with-cypresses |title=A Wheat Field, with Cypresses |year= |work=Collection, Vincent van Gogh |publisher=National Gallery, London |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref> which author H.W. Janson describes: "the field is like a stormy sea; the trees spring flamelike from the ground; and the hills and clouds heave with the same surge of motion. Every stroke stands out boldly in a long ribbon of strong, unmixed color."<ref name="Janson"/>
There is also another version of ''Wheat Fields with Cypresses'' made in September with a blue-green sky, reportedly held at the [[Tate Gallery]] in London (F743).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghgallery.com/catalog/Painting/748/Wheat-Field-with-Cypresses.html |title=Wheat Field with Cypresses |year=2011 |work=Van Gogh Paintings |publisher=Van Gogh Gallery |accessdate=April 10, 2011}}</ref>
====Other wheat field paintings==== Van Gogh describes the ripening ''[[Green Wheat Field with Cypress]]'' painted in June: "a field of wheat turning yellow, surrounded by blackberry bushes and green shrubs. At the end of the field there is a little house with a tall somber cypress which stands out against the far-off hills with their violet-like and bluish tones, and against a sky the colour of forget-me-nots with pink streaks, whose pure hues form a contrast with the scorched ears, which are already heavy, and have the warm tones of a bread crust."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.webexhibits.org/vangogh/letter/20/W12.htm |title=Letter from Vincent van Gogh to Wilhelmina van Gogh, Saint-Rémy, 16 June 1889 | editor=Harrison, R |year=2011 |work=Van Gogh Letters |publisher=WebExhibits (funded in part by U.S. Department of Education, Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education) |accessdate=April 6, 2011}}</ref>
In October Van Gogh made ''Enclosed Wheat Field with Ploughman.''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mfa.org/collections/object/enclosed-field-with-ploughman-35481 |title=Enclosed Wheat Field with Ploughman |year= |work=Collections |publisher=Museum of Fine Arts, Boston |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref> {{Clear}} <gallery mode="packed" heights="160"> File:Vincent van Gogh - Green Field - Google Art Project.jpg|''[[Green Wheat Field with Cypress]]'', 1889, Narodni Gallery, [[Prague]] (F719) File:Gogh, Vincent van - Landscape at Saint-Rémy (Enclosed Field with Peasant) - Google Art Project.jpg|''Enclosed Field with Peasant,'' October 1889, [[Indianapolis Museum of Art]], Indianapolis, Indiana File:Vincent van Gogh - Enclosed Field with Ploughman - Google Art Project.jpg|''Enclosed Wheat Field with Ploughman,'' October 1889, [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston|Museum of Fine Arts]], [[Boston]] (F706) </gallery> ''Wheat Fields in a Mountainous Landscape,'' also titled ''Meadow in the Mountains'' was painted in Late November - early December 1889.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kmm.nl/object/KM%20100.443/Wheat-fields-in-a-mountainous-landscape |title=Wheat Fields in a Mountainous Landscape |year= |work=Collection |publisher=Kröller-Müller Museum |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref>
In November, ''Wheat Field Behind Saint-Paul'' was painted by Van Gogh, now owned by Virginia Museum of Fine Arts.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghgallery.com/catalog/Painting/740/Wheat-Field-Behind-Saint-Paul-Hospital.html |title=Wheat Field Behind Saint-Paul |year= |work=Van Gogh Paintings |publisher=Van Gogh Gallery |accessdate=April 3, 2011}}</ref>
<gallery mode="packed" heights="160"> File:A Meadow in the Mountains Le Mas de Saint-Paul 1889 Vincent van Gogh.jpg|''Wheat Fields in a Mountainous Landscape,'' Late November-Early December 1889, [[Kröller-Müller Museum]], [[Otterlo]], [[Netherlands]] (F721) File:Vincent van Gogh - Landscape from Saint-Rémy - Google Art Project.jpg|''Wheat Field Behind Saint-Paul,'' November 1889, [[Virginia Museum of Fine Arts]], [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]], [[Virginia]] (F722) </gallery>
===Auvers-sur-Oise=== [[File:Gogh, Vincent van - Cottages.jpg|thumb|160px|right|''Thatched Cottages,'' 1890, [[Hermitage Museum|The Hermitage]], [[St. Petersburg]], Russia]]In May 1890, Van Gogh traveled from [[Saint-Rémy-de-Provence|Saint-Rémy]] to [[Paris]],<ref name="Wallace"/> where he had a three-day stay with his brother, [[Theo van Gogh (art dealer)|Theo]], Theo's wife [[Johanna van Gogh-Bonger|Johanna]] and their new baby Vincent. Van Gogh found that unlike his past experiences in Paris, he was no longer used to the commotion of the city<ref name="Leeuw">{{cite book | title=The Letters of Vincent van Gogh | author=Leeuw, R | publisher=Penguin Group | location=London and other locations | year=1997 | origyear=1996 | pages=488, 490, 491 | isbn= | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SyX5lfrof6oC&pg=PA329 }}</ref> and was too agitated to paint. His brother, Theo and artist [[Camille Pissarro]] developed a plan for Van Gogh to go to [[Auvers-sur-Oise]] with a letter of introduction for Dr. [[Paul Gachet]],<ref name="Wallace">{{cite book | title=The World of Van Gogh (1853-1890) | author=Wallace, R | publisher=Time-Life Books | location=Alexandria, VA, USA | year=1969 | pages=162–163 | isbn= | url= }}</ref> a homeopathic physician and art patron who lived in Auvers.<ref name="Strieter">{{cite book | title=Nineteenth-Century European Art: A Topical Dictionary | author=Strieter, T | publisher=Greenwood Press | location=Westport | year=1999 | page=17| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lDr7Tbk__1kC&pg=PA17 | isbn=0-313-29898-X }}</ref> Van Gogh had a room at the inn Auberge Ravoux in Auvers<ref name="Leeuw"/> and was under the care and supervision of Dr. Gachet with whom he grew to have a close relationship, "something like another brother."<ref name="Leeuw"/>
For a time, Van Gogh seemed to improve. He began to paint at such a steady pace, there was barely space in his room for all the finished paintings.<ref name="Wallace"/> From May until his death on July 29, Van Gogh made about 70 paintings, more than one a day, and many drawings.."<ref name="NGA">{{cite web |url=http://www.nga.gov/collection/gallery/vangogh/vangogh-46505.html |title=Girl in White, 1890 |year=2011 | work=The Collection |publisher=National Gallery of Art |accessdate=March 21, 2011}}</ref> Van Gogh painted buildings around the town of Auvers, such as [[The Church at Auvers]], portraits, and the nearby fields.<ref name="Leeuw"/>
Van Gogh arrived in Auvers in late spring as pea plants and wheat fields on gently sloping hills ripened for harvest. The area bustled as migrant workers from France and Brussels descended on the area for the harvest. Partial to rural life, Van Gogh strongly portrayed the beauty of the Auvers country side. He wrote his brother, "I have one study of old thatched roofs with a field of peas in flower in the foreground and some wheat, the background of hills, a study which I think you will like."<ref>{{cite book | title=Van Gogh's Table: At the Auberge Ravoux | first1=A | last1=Leaf | first2=F | last2=Lebain | publisher=Artisan | location=New York | year=2001 | page=136 | isbn= | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MBxJtWUz-CoC&pg=PA136 }}</ref>
====Wheat harvest series==== Van Gogh painted thirteen large canvases of horizontal landscapes of the wheat harvest that occurs in the region from the middle to late July. The series began with ''Wheat Field under Cloudy Sky'' then ''[[Wheatfield with Crows]]'' was painted when the crop was on the verge of harvest. ''Sheaves of Wheat'' painted after the harvest and concluding with "Field with Haystacks" (private collection).<ref name="Dallas">{{cite web |url=http://dallasmuseumofart.org |title=Sheaves of Wheat |date= |work=Collections |publisher=Dallas Museum of Art |accessdate=March 30, 2011}}</ref>
''Green Wheat Fields'' or ''Field with Green Wheat'' was made in May.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghgallery.com/catalog/Painting/181/Green-Wheat-Fields.html |title=Green Wheat Fields |year= |work=Van Gogh Paintings |publisher=Van Gogh Gallery |accessdate=April 3, 2011}}</ref>
''Wheat Field at Auvers with White House''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghgallery.com/catalog/Painting/739/Wheat-Field-at-Auvers-with-White-House.html |title=Wheat Field at Auvers with White House |year= |work=Van Gogh Paintings |publisher=Van Gogh Gallery |accessdate=April 3, 2011}}</ref> was made in June. The painting is mainly a large green field of wheat. In the background is a white house behind a wall and a tree.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.webexhibits.org/vangogh/letter/21/W23.htm |title=Letter from Vincent van Gogh to Wilhelmina van Gogh, Auvers-sur-Oise, c. 12 June 1890 | editor=Harrison, R |year=2011 |work=Van Gogh Letters |publisher=WebExhibits (funded in part by U.S. Department of Education, Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education) |accessdate=April 7, 2011}}</ref>
The outlying fields of Auvers, setting for ''Wheat Fields after the Rain (The Plain of Auvers),'' form a "zig-zag, patchwork pattern," of yellows, blues, and greens.<ref name="Carnegie">{{cite web |url=http://www.cmoa.org/searchcollections/details.aspx?item=1012404 |title=Wheat Fields after the Rain (The Plain of Auvers)| year=2007 |work=Explore the Collection |publisher=Carnegie Museum of Art |accessdate=March 30, 2011}}</ref> In the last letter that Van Gogh wrote to his mother he described being very calm, something needed for this work, an "immense plain with wheat fields up as far as the hills, boundless as the ocean, delicate yellow, delicate soft green, the delicate purple of a tilled and weeded piece of ground, with the regular speckle of the green of flowering potato plants, everything under a sky of delicate tones of blue, white, pink and violet."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.webexhibits.org/vangogh/letter/21/650.htm |title=Letter from Vincent van Gogh to His Parents, Auvers-sur-Oise, c. 10-14 July 1890 | editor=Harrison, R |year=2011 |work=Van Gogh Letters |publisher=WebExhibits (funded in part by U.S. Department of Education, Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education) |accessdate=April 6, 2011}}</ref> This painting was also called ''Wheat Fields at Auvers Under Clouded Sky.''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghgallery.com/catalog/Painting/754/Wheat-Fields-at-Auvers-Under-Clouded-Sky.html |title=Wheat Fields at Auvers Under Clouded Sky |year=2011 |work=Van Gogh Paintings |publisher=Van Gogh Gallery |accessdate=April 3, 2011}}</ref>
<gallery mode="packed" heights="160"> File:Van Gogh - Grünes Weizenfeld1.jpeg|''Field with Green Wheat,'' 1890, [[National Gallery of Art]], Washington, D.C. (F807) File:Van Gogh Wheat Field at Auvers with House.jpg|''Wheat Field at Auvers with White House,'' June 1890, [[The Phillips Collection]], Washington D.C. (F804) File:CarnegieMuseumofVincentGoghAfterRain.jpg|''Wheat Fields after the Rain (The Plain of Auvers),'' July 1890, [[Carnegie Museum of Art]], [[Pittsburgh]], PA (F781) </gallery> Van Gogh described ''Ears of Wheat'' to painter and friend [[Paul Gauguin]] as "nothing more than ears of wheat, green-blue stalks long, ribbon-like leaves, under a sheen of green & pink; ears of wheat, yellowing slightly, with an edge made pale pink by the dusty manner of flowering; at the bottom, a pink bindweed winding round a stalk. I would like to paint portraits against a background that is so lively and yet so still." The painting depicts "the soft rustle of the ears of grain swaying back and forth in the wind." He used the motif as the background to a portrait.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghmuseum.nl/vgm/index.jsp?page=3251&lang=en |title=Ears of Wheat |year= |work=Collection |publisher=Van Gogh Museum |accessdate=April 2, 2011}}</ref>
''The Fields'' was painted in July and held in a private collection.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghgallery.com/catalog/Painting/137/Fields,-The.html |title=The Fields |year= |work=Van Gogh Paintings |publisher=Van Gogh Gallery |accessdate=April 3, 2011}}</ref>
An animated ''Wheatfield with Cornflowers'' shows the effect of a gust of wind that ripples through the yellow stalks, seeming to "overflow" into the blue background. The heads of a few stalks of wheat seem to have detached themselves, diving into the blue of the hills in the background.<ref name="FB">{{cite web |url=http://www.fondationbeyeler.ch/en/collection/vincent-van-gogh |title=Vincent van Gogh |year=2010 |work=Collection |publisher=Fondation Beyeler |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref>
<gallery mode="packed" heights="160"> File:Van Gogh - Weizenhalme.jpeg|''Ears of Wheat,'' June 1890, [[Van Gogh Museum]], Amsterdam, Netherlands (F767) File:Van Gogh - Weizenfeld mit Gewitterhimmel.jpeg|''The Fields,'' July 1890, Private Collection (F761) File:Vincent Van Gogh - Wheatfield With Cornflowers - Google Art Project.jpg|''Wheat Field with Cornflowers,'' July 1890, Oil on canvas, 60 x 81 cm, [[Beyeler Foundation]], Riehen, Switzerland (F808) </gallery> ''Wheat Fields near Auvers,'' 1890, owned by [[Österreichische Galerie Belvedere]], Vienna<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghgallery.com/catalog/Painting/755/Wheat-Fields-near-Auvers.html |title=Wheat Fields near Auvers |year= |work=Van Gogh Paintings |publisher=Van Gogh Gallery |accessdate=April 3, 2011}}</ref> was also described by van Gogh as a landscape of the vast wheat fields after a rain.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.webexhibits.org/vangogh/letter/21/651.htm |title=Letter from Vincent van Gogh to Theo van Gogh, Auvers-sur-Oise, 23 July 1890 | editor=Harrison, R |year=2011 |work=Van Gogh Letters |publisher=WebExhibits (funded in part by U.S. Department of Education, Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education) |accessdate=April 6, 2011}}</ref>
Van Gogh brings the spectator directly into ''Sheaves of Wheat'' by filling the picture plane with eight sheaves of wheat, as if seeing it from a worker's perspective. The sheaves, bathed in yellow light, appear to be recently cut. For contrast, Van Gogh uses the complementary, vivid lavender for shadows and earth in the nearby field.<ref name="Dallas"/>
<gallery mode="packed" heights="160"> File:Vincent Willem van Gogh 038.jpg|''Wheat Fields near Auvers,'' 1890, [[Österreichische Galerie Belvedere]], Vienna (F775) File:Wheatfield - Van Gogh.jpg|''Sheaves of Wheat,'' 1890, [[Dallas Museum of Art]], [[Dallas]], Texas. (F771) </gallery> In van Gogh's ''Wheatfields Under Thunderclouds,'' also called ''Wheat Fields Under Clouded Sky,'' landscape he depicts the loneliness of the countryside and the degree to which it was "healthy and heartening."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghmuseum.nl/vgm/index.jsp?page=4596&lang=en |title=Wheatfields under Thunderclouds |year= |work=Collection |publisher=Van Gogh Museum |accessdate=April 2, 2011}}</ref>
The [[Van Gogh Museum]]'s ''[[Wheatfield with Crows]]'' was made in July 1890, in the last weeks of Van Gogh’s life, many have claimed it was his last work. Others have claimed ''Tree Roots'' was his last painting. ''Wheatfield with Crows,'' made on an elongated canvas, depicts a dramatic cloudy sky filled with crows over a wheat field.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghmuseum.nl/vgm/index.jsp?page=3343&lang=en#moretotell |title=Wheatfield with Crows |year= |work=Collection |publisher=Van Gogh Museum |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref> The wind-swept wheat field fills two thirds of the canvas. An empty path pulls the audience into the painting. Jules Michelet, one of Van Gogh's favorite authors, wrote of the crow: "They interest themselves in everything, and observe everything. The ancients, who lived far more completely than ourselves in and with nature, found it no small profit to follow, in a hundred obscure things where human experience as yet affords no light, the directions so prudent and sage a bird." Of making the painting Van Gogh wrote that he did not have a hard time depicting the sadness and emptiness of the painting, which was powerfully offset by the restorative nature of the countryside.<ref name="Edwards149">{{cite book | title=Van Gogh and God: A Creative Spiritual Quest | author=Edwards, C | publisher=Loyola Press | location=Chicago | year=1989 | pages=78, 186 | isbn=0-8294-0621-2 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fYA9QzwvsekC&pg=PA78 }}</ref> Erickson, author of ''Eternity's Gate: The Spiritual Vision of Vincent van Gogh'', cautious of attributing stylistic changes in his work to mental illness, finds the painting expresses both the sorrow and the sense of his life coming to an end.<ref name="Erickson103">{{cite book | title=At Eternity's Gate: The Spiritual Vision Of Vincent Van Gogh | author=Erickson, K | publisher=William B. Eerdsman Publishing | location=Grand Rapids, MI | year=1998 | pages=103, 148 | isbn=0-8028-3856-1 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Sz0Pla9mLSYC&pg=PA103}}</ref> The crows, used by Van Gogh as symbol of death and rebirth or resurrection, visually draw the spectator into the painting. The road, in contrasting colors of red and green, is thought to be a metaphor for a sermon he gave based on Bunyan's ''[[The Pilgrim's Progress]]'' where the pilgrim is sorrowful that the road is so long, yet rejoicing because the Eternal City waits at the journey's end.<ref name="Erickson162">{{cite book | title=At Eternity's Gate: The Spiritual Vision Of Vincent Van Gogh | author=Erickson, K | publisher=William B. Eerdsman Publishing | location=Grand Rapids, MI | year=1998 | pages=162–163 | isbn=0-8028-3856-1 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Sz0Pla9mLSYC&pg=PA162}}</ref>
''Wheat Stack Under Clouded Sky'' also called ''[[Haystacks in Provence|Haystack under a Rainy Sky]],'' was made July 1890, [[Kröller-Müller Museum]], [[Otterlo]], [[Netherlands]] (F563).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghgallery.com/catalog/Painting/187/Haystacks-under-a-Rainy-Sky.html |title=Haystacks Under a Rainy Sky |year= |work=Van Gogh Paintings |publisher=Van Gogh Gallery |accessdate=April 10, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kmm.nl/object/KM%20109.773/Wheat-stack-under-a-cloudy-sky |title=Wheat Stack Under a Cloudy Sky |year= |work= |publisher=Kröller-Müller Museum |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref>
<gallery mode="packed" heights="160"> File:Vincent van Gogh - Wheatfield under thunderclouds - Google Art Project.jpg|''Wheatfield Under Thunderclouds'', 1890, [[Van Gogh Museum]], Amsterdam, Netherlands (F778) File:Vincent van Gogh - Wheatfield with crows - Google Art Project.jpg|''[[Wheatfield with Crows]]'', July 1890, Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam (F779) File:Van Gogh - Heuschober an einem Regentag.jpeg|''Wheat Stack Under Clouded Sky'', July 1890, [[Kröller-Müller Museum]], [[Otterlo]], [[Netherlands]] (F563) </gallery> ''Field with Stacks of Grain,'' at [[Beyeler Foundation]], Riehen, Switzerland (F809) is one of van Gogh’s very last paintings, is both more rigid and at the same time more abstract than other paintings of this series, such as ''Wheatfield with Cornflowers.'' Two large stacks of wheat fill the painting like "abandoned buildings," seeming to cut off the sky.<ref name="FB"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghgallery.com/catalog/Painting/136/Field-with-Wheat-Stacks.html|title=Field with Stacks of Grain |year= |work=Van Gogh Paintings |publisher=Van Gogh Gallery |accessdate=April 3, 2011}}</ref>
''Wheat Fields with Auvers in the Background'' also painted in July is part of the Musée d'Art et d'Histoire collection in Geneva (F801).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghgallery.com/catalog/Painting/756/Wheat-Fields-with-Auvers-in-the-Background.html |title=Wheat Fields with Auvers in the Background |year= |work=Van Gogh Paintings |publisher=Van Gogh Gallery |accessdate=April 3, 2011}}</ref>
<gallery mode="packed" heights="160"> File:Van Gogh - Feld mit Korngarben.jpeg|''Field with Stacks of Grain,'' July 1890, [[Beyeler Foundation]], Riehen, Switzerland (F809) File:Van Gogh - Weizenfelder mit Blick auf Auvers.jpeg|''Wheat Fields with Auvers in the Background'', July 1890, Musée d'Art et d'Histoire, Geneva (F801). </gallery>
====Emotional turmoil==== From Wallace,<ref name="Wallace"/> "But for all his appearance of a renewed well-being his life was very near its end." Illness struck Theo's baby, Vincent. Theo had both health and employment issues; he considered leaving his employer and starting his own business. Gachet, said to have his own eccentricities and neurosis, caused van Gogh concern to which he questioned: "Now when one blind man leads another blind man, don't they both end up in the ditch?"<ref name="Leeuw"/><ref name="Wallace"/>
After visiting Paris for a family conference, Van Gogh returned to Auvers feeling more bleak. In a letter he wrote, "And the prospect grows darker, I see no future at all."<ref name="Wallace"/>
He later had a period where he said that "the trouble I had in my head has considerably calmed...I am completely absorbed in that immense plain covered with fields of wheat against the hills boundless as the sea in delicate colors of yellow and green, the pale violet of the plowed and weeded earth checkered at regular intervals with the green of the flowering potato plants, everything under a sky of delicate blue, white, pink, and violet. I am almost too calm, a state that is necessary to paint all that."
Four days after completing ''Wheat Fields after the Rain'' he shot himself in the Auvers wheat fields. Van Gogh died on July 29, 1890.<ref name="Carnegie"/>
